A priori, this is just a set, but if  is sufficiently small (i.e., “neat” in the sense of <cit.>), _K(G,X) can be canonically written as a finite disjoint union of hermitian symmetric domains.[If  fails to be sufficiently small, one might very reasonably argue that our definition of the Shimura variety of level  really is the definition of the coarse Shimura variety and that one should be working with stacks instead.]
More detailed explanations may be found in <cit.>.
For a (connected) reductive group  over , we denote by ℬ(G,K)ℬ^red(G,K)GK <cit.>.

  * ∅ℒ𝒪VΛ∈ℒϖΛ∈ℒ), 
  * cℒ→(ϖ^nΛ)=c(Λ)+n.
Note that this is (a variant of) a well-known theorem by van Dantzig if N={1} <cit.>.
By Kisin-Pappas <cit.> we do actually have such a diagram in our situation.
In <cit.>, Pappas and Zhu give a construction of the local model in quite a general context, in particular with no assumptions going beyond our running assumptions <ref>.
The local model M^loc_G,μ,KX_μ⊆_G×__p E__K,_p⊗__p𝒪_E__K,_p:=__K,__p^1⊗_^1__p, u↦ p_p is a base change of the global affine Graßmannian as defined in <cit.>.
SNNs have been a topic of active research with advances in architecture designs <cit.>, training methodologies <cit.>, <cit.> and practical deployments <cit.>, <cit.>.
They have been successfully applied to diverse pattern recognition tasks from object recognition <cit.> to EEG classification <cit.>.
Recently there have been works that show SNNs achieve comparable performances as the deep neural network architectures like VGG16 and Res-Nets for image classification tasks <cit.>.
<cit.> presented a first spike-based object detection model, called Spiking-YOLO.
<cit.> proposed a modified back-propagation based approach where the membrane potentials are treated as differentiable signals, and discontinuities at spike times are considered as noise.

There is also a training methodology that considers the relative timing between the pre-synaptic and post-synaptic spikes to influence the training of synaptic weights via an asymmetric learning window <cit.>.
<cit.> proposed an SNN training algorithm with continuous integration, which can handle input spikes with temporal information.
There are also Hebbian learning <cit.> based approaches that enable local training, unlike back-propagation.
<cit.> and was later applied and popularized for deep neural networks by Hinton et al.
<cit.>.
<cit.> use the final softmax outputs of a larger ANN to learn a smaller model by minimizing the squared difference between their activations.
The method in <cit.> is a more general one where the output logits are scaled by a temperature parameter to obtain soft thresholds and then used in the loss.
KD has been an active area of research with major applications in model compression <cit.>.
There have also been works that demonstrate improvement in the performance of a model when using KD based learning, e.g., in object detection <cit.>.

In addition to this, KD has also been used to improve the performance of various pattern recognition tasks when used as a training methodology for language understanding in <cit.> and sequence models in <cit.>.
<cit.> proposed that instead of minimizing cross-entropy with observed data, it is better to minimize cross-entropy with teacher's probability distribution.
<cit.> presents improvements in knowledge distillation by using an intermediate network they call teacher assistant.

sentence: Among manual methods,  tries to achieve obfuscation by instructing humans to either imitate the writing style of some author or just try to hide their own writing style.
citation_titles: ['{Adversarial stylometry: Circumventing authorship recognition to preserve privacy and anonymity}']
citation_authors: [[Person('Brennan, Michael'), Person('Afroz, Sadia'), Person('Greenstadt, Rachel')]]

sentence: Among semi-automated methods,  presents a tool called Anonymouth which analyzes the input document using an authorship attribution method and then suggest text-based changes.
citation_titles: ['{Use fewer instances of the letter “i”: Toward writing style anonymization}']
citation_authors: [[Person('McDonald, Andrew WE'), Person('Afroz, Sadia'), Person('Caliskan, Aylin'), Person('Stolerman, Ariel'), Person('Greenstadt, Rachel')]]

sentence: In order to achieve obfuscation,  uses rule-based text transformations to push the style of input document towards the average style of corpus.
citation_titles: ['{The case for being average: A mediocrity approach to style masking and author obfuscation}']
citation_authors: [[Person('Karadzhov, Georgi'), Person('Mihaylova, Tsvetomila'), Person('Kiprov, Yasen'), Person('Georgiev, Georgi'), Person('Koychev, Ivan'), Person('Nakov, Preslav')]]

sentence: In search-based methods,  uses genetic algorithms (GA) along with an authorship attribution method to identify words in a document, changing which will have the maximum adverse effect on authorship attribution.
citation_titles: ['{A Girl Has No Name: Automated Authorship Obfuscation using Mutant-X}']
citation_authors: [[Person('Mahmood, Asad'), Person('Ahmad, Faizan'), Person('Shafiq, Zubair'), Person('Srinivasan, Padmini'), Person('Zaffar, Fareed')]]

sentence: tries to achieve obfuscation by increasing the stylistic distance between input document and author's existing text.
citation_titles: ['{Heuristic Authorship Obfuscation}']
citation_authors: [[Person('Bevendorff, Janek'), Person('Potthast, Martin'), Person('Hagen, Matthias'), Person('Stein, Benno')]]

sentence: Apart from these, there are also a couple of model-based approaches  which train a deep learning model to generate obfuscated documents.
citation_titles: ['{A4NT: author attribute anonymity by adversarial training of neural machine translation}', '{Style Obfuscation by Invariance}']
citation_authors: [[Person('Shetty, Rakshith'), Person('Schiele, Bernt'), Person('Fritz, Mario')], [Person('Emmery, Chris'), Person('Manjavacas, Enrique'), Person('Chrupa{\\l}a, Grzegorz')]]

sentence: uses stylometric features to perform obfuscation detection on manually obfuscated documents.
citation_titles: ['Detecting stylistic deception']
citation_authors: [[Person('Juola, Patrick')]]

sentence: also performs manual obfuscation detection using stylistic features.
citation_titles: ['Detecting hoaxes, frauds, and deception in writing style online']
citation_authors: [[Person('Afroz, Sadia'), Person('Brennan, Michael'), Person('Greenstadt, Rachel')]]

sentence: uses stylometric analysis to detect whether a document was generated using text spinners or not.
citation_titles: ['Accurate detection of automatically spun content via stylometric analysis']
citation_authors: [[Person('Shahid, Usman'), Person('Farooqi, Shehroze'), Person('Ahmad, Raza'), Person('Shafiq, Zubair'), Person('Srinivasan, Padmini'), Person('Zaffar, Fareed')]]

sentence: helps humans in detecting whether a given piece of text is written by a human or a particular language model called GPT-2.
citation_titles: ['{GLTR}: Statistical Detection and Visualization of Generated Text']
citation_authors: [[Person('Gehrmann, Sebastian'), Person('Strobelt, Hendrik'), Person('Rush, Alexander')]]

sentence: They achieve this by extracting probability distribution of words given their context, using a pre-trained GPT-2  and then providing this information to humans.
citation_titles: ['Language models are unsupervised multitask learners']
citation_authors: [[Person('Radford, Alec'), Person('Wu, Jeffrey'), Person('Child, Rewon'), Person('Luan, David'), Person('Amodei, Dario'), Person('Sutskever, Ilya')]]

sentence: performs neural fake news detection by identifying if the given news article is written by a human or their fake news generation model called GROVER.
citation_titles: ['Defending Against Neural Fake News']
citation_authors: [[Person('Zellers, Rowan'), Person('Holtzman, Ari'), Person('Rashkin, Hannah'), Person('Bisk, Yonatan'), Person('Farhadi, Ali'), Person('Roesner, Franziska'), Person('Choi, Yejin')]]

sentence: also tries to distinguish between human and language model generated text.
citation_titles: ['{Real or Fake? Learning to Discriminate Machine from Human Generated Text}']
citation_authors: [[Person('Bakhtin, Anton'), Person('Gross, Sam'), Person('Ott, Myle'), Person('Deng, Yuntian'), Person("Ranzato, Marc'Aurelio"), Person('Szlam, Arthur')]]

sentence: Boundary Attack  is one of the first work that uses final decisions of a classifier to perform blackbox attacks.
citation_titles: ['Decision-based adversarial attacks: Reliable attacks against black-box machine learning models']
citation_authors: [[Person('Brendel, Wieland'), Person('Rauber, Jonas'), Person('Bethge, Matthias')]]

sentence: propose to choose the random perturbation in each step more wisely instead of Gaussian perturbation, using Perlin noise, alpha distribution and DCT respectively.
citation_titles: ['Guessing smart: Biased sampling for efficient black-box adversarial attacks', 'Black-Box Decision based Adversarial Attack with Symmetric alpha-stable Distribution', 'Low frequency adversarial perturbation']
citation_authors: [[Person('Brunner, Thomas'), Person('Diehl, Frederik'), Person('Le, Michael Truong'), Person('Knoll, Alois')], [Person('Srinivasan, Vignesh'), Person('Kuruoglu, Ercan E'), Person('M{\\"u}ller, Klaus-Robert'), Person('Samek, Wojciech'), Person('Nakajima, Shinichi')], [Person('Guo, Chuan'), Person('Frank, Jared S'), Person('Weinberger, Kilian Q')]]

sentence: propose a similar idea - approximating the gradient around the boundary using Monte Carlo algorithm.
citation_titles: ['Black-box adversarial attacks with limited queries and information', 'RED-Attack: Resource Efficient Decision based Attack for Machine Learning', 'A geometry-inspired decision-based attack', 'Hopskipjumpattack: A query-efficient decision-based attack']

sentence: proposes to transform the boundary-based output into a continuous metric, so that the score-based attack techniques can be adopted.

sentence: In , the authors draw intuition from JPEG codec  image compression techniques and propose to use discrete cosine transform (DCT) for generating low frequency adversarial perturbations to assist score-based adversarial attack.
citation_titles: ['Low frequency adversarial perturbation', 'The JPEG still picture compression standard']
citation_authors: [[Person('Guo, Chuan'), Person('Frank, Jared S'), Person('Weinberger, Kilian Q')], [Person('Wallace, Gregory K')]]

sentence: AutoZoom  trains an auto-encoder offline with natural images and uses the decoder network as a dimension reduction tool.
citation_titles: ['Autozoom: Autoencoder-based zeroth order optimization method for attacking black-box neural networks']
